awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE Incubator: U2-SAFE: Unifying Undergraduate Student Access to Field Experiences using The Virtual Field Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will create a new network composed of staff at field stations and marine labs combined with faculty and students at community colleges, tribal colleges, professional student organizations, and minority serving institutions, and educators with video content creators. This research coordination network incubator will take the virtual learning products developed for the Virtual Field platform (thevirtualfield.org) in response to COVID-19 travel restrictions and improve and refine them with feedback from students. Only a small proportion of the hundreds of thousands of college students can be hosted at natural areas to conduct research and take classes. This project brings underwater coastal marine and estuarine communities, vast grasslands, alpine forests, and rocky foothills into the classroom with both recorded and live instruction and real scientists and graduate students as role models, enabling a broader range of college students to experience, observe, catalog, and explore the natural world. Place-based learning experiences have a profound effect on undergraduate students, creating deeper connections with the concepts studied, a long-term engagement in sciences, and exposure to developing STEM careers unfamiliar to these audiences.

With a global distribution of 1268 terrestrial, coastal, and marine stations, over 75% affiliated with universities, Field Stations and Marine Labs (FSMLs) are in a unique position to respond to the needs of the next generation of undergraduate biology students. Unfortunately, many students are unable to visit these often-remote locations where hands-on research can be conducted. In addition, it can be extremely difficult to conduct cross-site comparative research in locations that are far apart. This project will take the videos and curriculum created previously, train FSML staff and associated faculty to develop additional material and hone the results with direct feedback from faculty and students to create adaptive modules for a variety of disciplines from geology to hydrology to biology.

This project is funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure, as part of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange/finalreport/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this incubator Research Coordination Network (RCN) project were to create a network of faculty located at institutions with limited opportunities for field science experiences such as minority serving institutions (MSIs), urban campuses, four-year liberal arts schools, two-year community colleges, or historically black colleges and universities, who would be willing to use The Virtual Field (TVF) material found at thevirtualfield.org in their classrooms.  We held workshops with these faculty discussing curriculum and virtual field educational materials and brought in content creators like videographers, filmmakers, and virtual reality and augmented reality experts. Together, with field station and marine lab (FSML) directors who made these short nature-based observation films at their sites, we discussed what did and did not work in the classroom and how TVF platform and contents can evolve to help meet the curricular needs of the faculty.

We wanted the faculty to give us feedback to improve the videos and refine and test-drive curriculum and exercises designed to go with the videos. We used a series of surveys to gather that feedback. Along the way, we evaluated the success of the network formation and the usefulness of the videos in the classroom for teaching observation skills. Lastly, we wanted to provide tools for engagement for FSML directors and methods to increase access to their sites to broader audiences, particularly university instructors and students.

Our end goal was to build a robust collaborative network of faculty, FSMLs, and students working together on effective incorporation of virtual materials into academic courses in ways that mimic the high-impact outcomes of in-person field trips. The long-term result of this new network is that it allows faculty at MSIs to leverage existing FSML resources - both virtual and in-person - to encourage underrepresented students to experience science in a new and engaging way. We hope a greater number of underrepresented students can see themselves as scientists and positively perceive the scientific process of observing what occurs in nature unimpeded.

The strongest evidence of robust network creation came at the end of the final workshop in June when every RCN participant expressed interest in remaining involved in a future RCN proposal. They were also eager to recommend other faculty and audiences that would meet the goals of expanding and enhancing field experiences for traditionally underrepresented students.

Seventeen faculty members used TVF materials in at least 21 courses during the 2021/2022 school year, reaching over 1000 students. The majority (57%) of these courses were for subject majors, and half of the courses were entry-level courses.

Faculty users reported that using TVF in their courses expanded access to ecosystems that were far away via virtual visits or to local ecosystems at a different time of year. For example, New York City faculty teaching in the winter quarter could virtually visit Black Rock Forest, a site that is 60 miles away, in the spring when vegetation is not dormant. The design and flexibility of the TVF exercises engaged different students' strengths, which faculty found especially important in courses for non-science majors. Faculty reported that ESL students could also engage with the materials without modification.

The faculty experience in the RCN was overwhelmingly positive across all three aspects. Faculty felt seen and heard in all RCN activities and collaborated in building and sharing course materials. Faculty used all four scaffolded exercises provided on TVF, with the majority (62%) of courses utilizing all four. Students in these courses rated them moderately effective to very effective in increasing their skills. While limited, evidence supports that faculty were using TVF to enrich their teaching and improve student learning, either by providing a meaningful experience in a local ecosystem that students cannot access or by expanding access to the ecosystems they exposed their students to.

The products of the RCN reached hundreds of field station and marine lab directors through articles written for the Organization of Biological Field Station's membership list serv, through Facebook, and via workshops held at OBFS annual meetings and free zoom seminars. Online talks about the project were given to interested groups such as at the Ecological Society of America's annual meeting and at the University of California's Natural Reserve meeting. The Virtual Field website itself was accessed by thousands of users who contributed content, used the material in their classroom, or explored the various field stations and ecosystems represented to better understand our world and the science that occurs at these sites every day.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Sarah Oktay
